Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

This award will permit the renovation of several research facilities at the Mount Wilson Observatory (MWO). This observatory was founded in 1904 in the San Gabriel Mountains of Southern California, remains an active research site in spite of the night sky illumination from the Los Angeles basin. The original 60- and 150-ft solar towers, which established the field of solar physics, are used by teams from the University of Southern California and UCLA to study the sun's surface activity and magnetic field as well as probing its interior using the techniques of helioseismology. UC Berkeley operates the Infrared Spatial Interferometer, a mid-infrared 3-telescope facility with a unique capability for studying supergiant and giant stars and their dusty environments. Mount Wilson is home to Georgia State University's Center for High Angular Resolution Astronomy whose CHARA Array is the world's highest resolution optical interferometer.

The Observatory has been managed since 1987 under an agreement with the Carnegie Institution of Washington, owner of the original Observatory facilities, by the Mount Wilson Institute (MWI), a non-profit organization incorporated in California with offices in Atlanta. MWI seeks to renovate certain facilities that date from the Observatory's beginnings that have received no major attention in decades. These tasks include painting and repairs of solar towers and the original night-time telescopes presently in danger of serious malfunction due to lack of such maintenance, repair of tanks and delivery systems used for supplying potable and fire-fighting water, and reduction of vegetation that fuels forest fires. Many of these tasks involve human safety and all are fundamental to the continued operation of Mount Wilson Observatory as a scientific research site.

Ongoing research efforts from Mount Wilson all involve the training of the next generation of astronomers and further public awareness of astronomical research. Undergraduate students are associated directly with four principal projects as well as with a special two-week summer program. MWI has updated the Astronomical Museum on the mountain to more clearly depict the historical contribution from MWO as well as better inform the public of its contemporary science programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Founded in 1904, Mount Wilson Observatory, located in the San Gabriel Mountains of Southern California, launched modern astronomy and created the field of astrophysics. From 1908 until 1949, the Observatory possesed the world's largest telescopes, and the quest for ever larger telescopes was launched from that mountain on which new techologies were developed and employed for exploiting the inherent excellent seeing conditions provided by the stable air moving in from the cold Pacific Ocean.

While the brightening skies of the Los Angeles basin stopped research at the remotest and hences faintest regions of the Universe, the excellent seeing conditions continue to make MWO an ideal location from which to conduct high resolution imaging studies of stars. Thus, the Observatory is home not only to the original nighttime and solar telescopes but also hosts the CHARA Array (see www.chara.gsu.edu/CHARA), the world's most powerful instrument for zooming in on stars to see them as other than point sources of light.

In order to preserve Mount Wilson as an operational observatory into the 21st Century, this grant was utilized to repair and upgrade infrastructure items critical to the continuing operation of its historic telescopes, most notably the 60-ft and 150-ft Solar Tower Telescopes and the 60-inch and 100-inch reflector telescopes. A major expenditure from this grant has been to paint the telescopes and their enclosing domes and towers, an activity that has not been carried out in a generation, much to the detriment of these facilities. In addition, funds were used to mitigate the threat of forest fires in the immediate vicinities of telescopes, repair stairways, railings and other human safety factors to decrease risk of injury to scientists in conducting their observations, and to make other repairs, such as replacement of an obsolete air conditioning system in the 60-ft Solar Tower, necessary for continuing science operations.

The intellectual merits of this effort are broad as evidenced by the diversity of scientific projects carried out from Mount Wilson. The solar telescopes continue their pioneering roles in measuring the acoustic oscillations in the sun's surface, which were originally discovered at the 60-ft Solar Tower, as well as in monitoring the behavior of the sun's magnetic field. The nighttime telescopes provide platforms for experiments and monitoring programs not suitable for other national or private observatories. In recent years, such efforts have involved measurement of orbital motions in double star systems, and surveys of stars used as calibrating objects for potential space-based searches for exoplanets around other stars.

This work also feeds into the Observatory's broader impact, particularly in the training of the next generation of astronomers through research activities on the mountain by graduate and postdoctoral students as well as through a continuing summer program for undergraduates with an interest in astronomy. The Observatory has two museums, one dating to 1937 and the second more modern facility devoted to science and technology from the CHARA Array. Mount Wilson is also a popular destination for visitors to Southern California with thousdands of people coming to the mountaintop each year to learn about the Observatory's more than a century of contributions to the field of astronomy.
